awd_titl_txt: Standard: The Ethics of Diversity--Fortifying Ethical Infrastructure to Prevent and Address Sexual Harassment in STEM Research & Practice Settings
awd_abstract_narration:
Sexual harassment is a major ethical issue across science and engineering fields, but research on this topic is relatively rare in studies of scientific ethics. This project will examine sexual harassment in science and the social contexts in which it occurs to understand how best to prevent and address sexual harassment in STEM settings. The investigators will do so first by conducting a comprehensive literature review to determine the kinds of the policies and practices that lead to ethical climates that prevent and remediate sexual harassment. They will then develop a self-assessment tool that will enable organizations to examine their ability to prevent and manage sexual harassment, and to evaluate if and how the self-assessment tool contributes to improved ethical infrastructures for preventing sexual harassment. Finally, they will develop a teaching module focused on sexual harassment for undergraduate and graduate students that will enhance ethical training and communication. The main project goal is to understand the conditions that contradict sexual harassment in STEM and empower research institutions to strengthen their ethical infrastructures related to sexual harassment. 

This project will facilitate a more nuanced and realistic understanding of the social and organizational conditions associated with sexual harassment in STEM, and of methods, principles, and strategies for overcoming and preventing it. This project is conceptually innovative in theorizing sexual harassment as resulting from interactions among formal institutional systems, informal influences, and local cultures and climates, rather than simply the behavior of one or two unethical 'bad apples'. It is methodologically innovative in applying a multimodal, multi-wave research design that combines comprehensive literature reviews with social surveys and in-depth interviews to advance basic understanding of these issues and to create a self-assessment tool with broad utility across the sciences and engineering. Project findings and the self-assessment tool will be broadly disseminated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ethical research and practice require that individuals in colleges, universities, and STEM settings feel safe, secure, and respected. Sexual harassment shatters the bedrock of safe and healthy environments on which ethical institutions are built. For decades, experts have recognized the deleterious effects of sexual harassment in higher education on both the individual and institutional levels. 

To help higher education institutions avoid the serious problems and negative consequences related to sexual harassment, the researchers developed an approach and mechanism for higher education institutions to proactively address sexual harassment by faculty, administrators and other persons in supervisory positions. The overall goal of the project was to develop a self-assessment tool for institutions to systematically examine and improve how they prevent and address sexual harassment in higher education and STEM settings.To attain this goal, the researchers identified the policies, procedures, practices, and influences that contribute to the establishment and maintenance of ethical culture and climate for the prevention and remediation of sexual harassment.

Based on the results of a comprehensive literature review on sexual harassment in higher education, STEM, business, industry, and the military, the researchers identified best and promising practices for fostering climates and cultures where sexual harassment is not tolerated and is effectively addressed. Using the findings from the literature review and four empirical studies in STEM departments at a large research university, they developed questions based on the best and promising practices derived from the research studies, expert commentary, and authoritative material. These questions cover the full range of issues related to addressing sexual harassment, including the implementation of comprehensive policies, impactful training, and effective complaints-handling procedures, as well as more institution-wide concerns related  to climate, culture, and leadership's role and commitment to preventing sexual harassment. The Self-Assessment Tool for Improving How Higher Education Institutions and STEM Units Address Sexual Harassment by Faculty and Administrators is designed to be a user-friendly instrument that enables individuals and teams to systematically evaluate how their institutions, schools, and departments currently handle sexual harassment and to improve by learning about best and promising practices, as well as the research and other material that is linked to each question. Rather than continuing to deal with harassment on a reactive and piecemeal basis, the self-assessment tool will enable institutions to tranform their approach to sexual harassment. 

By empowering institutions to examine and improve how they prevent and address sexual harassment, the self-assessment tool promises to improve the learning and work environments for all students and employees. By making STEM settings safer and more equitable, universities and colleges will also improve the recruitment and retention of women and other members of groups that are currently underrepresented in STEM. Such outcomes contribute to the development of a more diverse STEM workforce.

To enhance the training and communication of ethical standards related to sexual harassment, project team members also developed and evaluated teaching materials for use in Engineering Ethics courses. These materials will equip faculty and instructors to engage students in considering the role of inclusion and respect in working in fields that are increasingly multicultural and diverse. Such learning experiences may improve students learning and work cultures while students are in school and thereafter. The study may also contribute to the ethical treatment and well-being of others in society who work and deal with STEM graduates.
